elements.label: Mike Brunt
elements.bio: My career has spanned Information Technology since 1982, currently I am working on two blockchain-based projects.  In addition, I am a Permaculture Certified designer and an artist, composer and musician.
elements.work: Currently I co-run the Eugene Permaculture Meetup group and am actively involved in several Urban Permaculture projects, in and around Eugene.
elements.statement: The whole concept of bioregionalism is key to our futures everywhere, Bill Mollison saw this years ago and David Holmgren followed up on this with Retro-Suburbia.  We are seeing the failure of globalism and now is the time to get back to our bioregional roots.  Bring back the village.

elements.label: Jon Van Meter
elements.bio: Control room Supervisor for local area television stations, and I communicate daily with News director and assignment editor in the Eugene area with broadcast to Florence, Roseburg and Coos Bay.

elements.label: Department of Bioregion
elements.description: The Department of Bioregion is a 501(c)3 nonprofit and social movement to build a planetary network of interconnected bioregions and bioregional movements.
elements.importence: The Department of Bioregion is a hosting organization for the Regenerate Cascadia activation tour and summit in October of 2023. We hope to use this tour to activate on-the-ground leaders and land stewards with a governance structure able to steward a bioregional regeneration fund.

elements.label: Nate Bade
elements.bio: I am a data scientist from Cascadia!
elements.work: I do some backend work for the Kumu mapping and data organization.
elements.statement: I feel it is a much more economically and socially sensible way to organize the geography of society.

elements.label: Brandon Letsinger
elements.bio: My name is Brandon Letsinger. I'm the founder of CascadiaNow! and the Department of Bioregion, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to building a world of planetary bioregions and interconnected bioregional movements. I am working with Clare Attwell to help convene the Regenerate Cascadia campaign and was a steward in the Salmon Nation edge prize program.

elements.label: Clare Attwell
elements.bio: Clare Attwell has long worked in community cultural development from the local to provincial level, and is also a textile and multi-media artist. She currently works with several local and global communities deeply engaged in every aspect of Earth Regeneration. These include the Design School For Regenerating Earth, Regenerate Cascadia, for which she is the co-founder, and Conversations for a One Planet Region Society, a local, Victoria based non-profit helping to catalyze a Bioregional conversation across the region.
elements.work:
Clare Attwell, B.A., Arts Admin.

Community Artist & Weaver

Since the 1990’s, Clare has worked across scales, from grassroots through to the municipal and provincial levels of decision making, to develop scaffolding to support Community Cultural Development.  Her early work in this area, has informed most of her work since.

Clare currently works with several communities deeply engaged in work involving every aspect of Earth Regeneration. These include the Design School For Regenerating Earth, Regenerate Cascadia, for which she is the co-founder, and Conversations for a One Planet Region Society, a local, Victoria based non-profit helping to catalyze a Bioregional conversation across the region.

Clare is also a textile and multi-media artist. When she is not working on her own art, she works as a community artist, using the arts in imaginative ways to help community groups explore complex issues such as cultural and spiritual identity, including community visioning.  Clare is especially interested in exploring what makes complex systems functional, and in particular, how they relate to organizations and social systems.

https://clareattwellartist.wordpress.com

While I was still in my early teens, I realized that noble efforts that don't connect to people’s hearts, - and where a sense of belonging is absent - , do not create the kind of systems-change required for the world we want.  This was the work I felt called to, despite the fact that no such paid job existed, contrary to appearances.  Thus, for the last 3 decades, I have split my time earning a basic income in unrelated work in order to spend most of my time working as an unpaid weaver, artist in residence, community animator, - using the lens of Community Cultural Development.

My focus has now broadened to using a whole-landscape scale lens for creating the conditions for learning how to ‘bioregion’ together - where the arts, growing food, Earth regeneration, 'yarning' and laughing together, using polycentric governance processes, feature prominently!

“The map is not the territory - A Korzypski

elements.label: Conversations For A One Planet Region Society
elements.description: Through the Conversations for a One Planet Region we want to engage, educate and empower people across the Greater Victoria Region to discuss the challenges and strengths of becoming a One Planet Region.
elements.importence: Our vision is that the Greater Victoria Region achieves social and ecological sustainability, with a high quality of life and a long life in good health for all its citizens, while reducing its ecological footprint to be equivalent to one planet’s worth of biocapacity. Our Mission is very simple: to establish and maintain community-wide conversations on One Planet living and a One Planet Region.

elements.label: midi berry
elements.work: Earth Regenerators, Vivero Steward and Ambassador
elements.statement: Cascadia was the first US bioregion I lived in for two and a half years during the mid-70's and it was already more environmentally aware than other places I'd lived. I fell in love with the land and returned in the early 90's to study for some months when the Process Work group I had been studying with moved from Europe to Portland. My contact with Oregon resumed after immigrating to Southern California in 2001. While participating in Edge Prize I met Cascadia people online and learned about many amazing activities and projects. As a southern outpost of Salmon Nation, I feel an affinity with my northern neighbours. I engage in bioregional work through online networking as well as on-ground and wish to support Regenerate Cascadia however I might be of practical service.

elements.label: Christine Lorenz
elements.bio:
Just starting to learn about regeneration.
Worked in a nonprofit research group in the behavioral sciences.
Massage therapist well.
elements.statement: Yes. That’s why I wanted to join this group on the Cascadia tour.
